content.question: The rate at which rain accumulates in a bucket is modeled by the function <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> given by <math alttext="r of t, equals, 10 t, minus t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="r of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in milliliters per minute and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes since the rain began falling. How many milliliters of rain accumulate in the bucket from time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
